It is considered good practice to use the type-safe equality operators===and!==instead of their regular counterparts==and!=.
The reason for this is that==and!=do type coercion which follows the rather obscureAbstract Equality Comparison Algorithm.
For instance, the following statements are all consideredtrue:
[] == false[] == ![]3 == "03"
If one of those occurs in an innocent-looking statement such asa == bthe actual problem is very difficult to spot.
